user_request: Write a poem about a traveler at a fork in a yellow wood who chooses the less-traveled path.

revision_history.draft:
# Radio Frequency

At the split I left my phone inside its case,
cased in its own silence, floating somewhere
between four walls of black and something
thinner, greening in the hum of earth.

The wood does not speak but it sponges.
It takes the frequency from everything that moves—

your heartbeat read six miles out,
a drone's descent tracked like a psalm—
and what I carried against my chest
gradually darkened into nothing
until the screen became a thing
less real than the concept of a screen.

I followed the road less populated
by light. The other path smelled of copper
gone to rust, of tin immersed in ferns,
of data dying small and patient
in the soil's black furred stomach.

The fork was not a question.
It was an amputation.

Somewhere underneath the hum
a phone answers no one.
Its operating system dreams
of signals that have never left.

I pressed my palm to what remained
and felt—a circuit, yes,
but also the nerve of a tree
learning how to ask for nothing.

The moss had closed over every name.
Over every tower. Over every frequency
that came seeking its own reflection
found only glass and green and the deep
particular quiet where information
goes to rest forever, cooled,
absorbed into the living dark
as something it can no longer give back.

I sat where the wood was thick enough
to swallow even black. The moss held my name
like a coat. I ate berries
and did not wonder who had put them there—
the body produces its own superfluousness,
its own fruit, its own reason to stay.

There is a loneliness that keeps records.
There is a kind that doesn't need
to. The fork chose mine.
I stayed. The trees kept everything
except for me, and even that
slowly, over centuries, let go.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

### 1. What's Alive

The refrain "the fork chose mine" is the poem's true spine — it shifts meaning each time it returns, and that's where the intelligence lives. The closing movement from "kept everything / except for me, and even that / slowly, over centuries, let go" earns its weight because of what precedes it; the accumulation of specific material detail (moss holding a name like a coat, berries appearing without attribution) builds trust in the speaker's strangeness.

The line "I followed the road less populated / by light" — that's precise and strange enough to land. The poem is at its strongest when it resists paraphrase: when it holds an image rather than explaining what the image means.

The circuit-board-as-bone metaphor (circuit boards rust like bones) works because it stays physical; it doesn't sentimentalize.

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Cliché / dead language:** "deep / particular quiet where information / goes to rest forever" — this is the poem reaching for grandeur and failing. "Rest forever, cooled" is a cliché dressed in scientific diction. The poem has already done better with "its own superfluousness, / its own fruit, its own reason to stay." Cut or replace.

**Abstraction bloat:** Lines 39–45 are the weakest stretch:
> There is a loneliness that keeps records.
> There is a kind that doesn't need
> to. The fork chose mine.
> I stayed. The trees kept everything
> except for me, and even that
> slowly, over centuries, let go.

This is summary of what the poem has already shown us in physical terms. "A loneliness that keeps records" — this is a thesis statement, not poetry. **Direction:** Cut or radically compress these lines. Trust the image of moss swallowing names. Trust the amputation refrain. The fork chose *what*? Not *loneliness*. What did it choose?

**Redundancy / structural padding:** "I left my phone inside its case" appears in line 2 and returns in line 13 ("carried against my chest"). "Cased in its own silence, floating somewhere" — this is three gestures doing one thing. **Direction:** Choose the strongest version of each setup. The poem opens with a dead phone; don't restate it.

**Weak transition / filler:** "It was an amputation." This line does nothing except name what happened. It's the least interesting thing to say about a fork that chose something. **Direction:** Replace with imagery — let the reader arrive at the conclusion without being told.

**"Your heartbeat read six miles out, / a drone's descent tracked like a psalm"—** "Tracked like a psalm" is decorative personification. The poem has already shown us light and copper and ferns; it

---
# Radio Frequency

At the split I left my phone inside its case,
cased in its own silence, floating somewhere
between four walls of black and something
thinner, greening in the hum of earth.

The wood absorbs.
It takes the frequency from everything that moves—

your heartbeat read six miles out,
a drone's descent tracked like a psalm—
and what I carried against my chest
gradually darkened into nothing
until the screen became a thing
less real than the concept of a screen.

I followed the road less populated
by light. The other path smelled of copper
gone to rust, of tin immersed in ferns,
of data dying small and patient
in the soil's black furred stomach.

The fork was not a question.
It was an amputation.

Somewhere underneath the hum
a phone answers no one.
Its operating system dreams
of signals that have never left.

I pressed my palm to what remained
and felt—a circuit, yes,
but also the nerve of a tree
learning how to ask for nothing.

The moss had closed over every name.
Over every tower. Over every frequency
that came seeking its own reflection
found only glass and green and the deep
particular quiet where information
goes to rest forever, cooled,
absorbed into the living dark
as something it can no longer give back.

I sat where the wood was thick enough
to swallow even black. The moss held my name
like a coat. I ate berries
and did not wonder who had put them there—
the body produces its own superfluousness,
its own fruit, its own reason to stay.

There is a loneliness that keeps records.
There is a kind that doesn't need
to. The fork chose mine.
I stayed. The trees kept everything
except for me, and even that
slowly, over centuries, let go.
---

revision_history.draft:
At the split I left my phone inside its case,
cased in its own silence, floating somewhere
between four walls of black and something
thinner, greening in the hum of earth.

The wood absorbs.
It takes the frequency from everything that moves—

your heartbeat read six miles out,
a drone's descent tracked like a psalm—
and what I carried against my chest
gradually darkened into nothing
until the screen became a thing
less real than the concept of a screen.

I followed the road less crowded
by light. The other path smelled of rusted copper,
of damp tin, of data slowing down
in the soil's black furrow—patient,
still carrying messages for no one.

What the fork took was physical:
a groove carved into the wood's grain,
the soft oak darkened where it pressed.

Somewhere underneath the hum
a phone answers no one.
Its circuits cool and taken up
by moss and spore, by the slow
particular quiet where information
goes to rest forever, absorbed
into the living dark as something
it can no longer give back.

I sat where the wood was thick enough
to swallow even black. The moss held my name
like a coat. I ate berries
and did not wonder who had put them there—
the body produces its own superfluousness,
its own fruit, its own reason to stay.

There are two kinds of silence:
one that keeps records and one that doesn't.
The fork chose mine. I stayed.
The trees kept everything
except for me, and even that
slowly, over centuries, let go.

At the split I left my phone inside its case,
cased in its own silence, floating somewhere
between black and something thinner—
the green of earth pressed into bark.

The wood absorbs.
It takes the frequency from everything that moves—

your heartbeat read six miles out,
a drone's descent a slow tremor—
and what I carried against my chest
darkened into nothing until the screen became
less real than the concept of a screen.

I followed the road less crowded by light. The other path
smelled of rusted copper, damp tin,
data slowing down in black furrow — patient,
still carrying messages for no one.

The fork pressed deep, carved grooves
into the wood's grain, soft oak darkened where it pressed.

Somewhere underneath the hum
a phone answers no one.
Its circuits cooled and entered moss and spore,
the slow particular quiet where information
goes to rest forever absorbed
into living dark as something
it can no longer give back.

I sat where the wood was thick enough
to swallow even black. The moss held my name
like a coat. I ate berries
and did not wonder who had put them there —

the body produces its own superfluousness,
its own fruit, its own reason to stay.

There are two kinds of silence:
one that keeps records and one that doesn't.
The fork chose mine. I stayed.
The trees kept everything except for me,
and even that slowly, over centuries,
let go.
